2E10B303A1DA4AFEA7E4457759F4ADB3.description:
Electrophilic substitution reactions include the reactions of benzene with
electrophiles.

DD4C03097D9A453F9DC1829A1D3348FE.description:
The relative stability of carbocations in the addition reactions between
hydrogen halides and unsymmetrical alkenes can be used to explain the reaction mechanism.

D3E9A57D1E73478281D2DB1B8FC3E315.description: Alkenes readily undergo electrophilic addition reactions.

C48413150413477E8C299B0C87DA7FF1.description:
The rate of the substitution reactions is influenced by the identity of the leaving
group.

A3C2A0945BCE417E931894C35F09D766.description:
Nucleophilic substitution reactions include the reactions between
halogenoalkanes and nucleophiles.

E864A0D0C1FD4EB6BCB7B70EB47D5EEF.description:
Coordination bonds are formed when ligands donate an electron pair to
transition element cations, forming complex ions.

DBF0A84C5E1B481CBF19671FF398083D.description:
When a Lewis base reacts with a Lewis acid, a coordination bond is formed.
Nucleophiles are Lewis bases and electrophiles are Lewis acids.

524AB6D320E64E608AEF7B75306F5093.description:
A Lewis acid is an electron-pair acceptor and a Lewis base is an electron-pair
donor.

B02162A6373647978DD8BD38F1C9F292.description:
Alkenes are susceptible to electrophilic attack because of the high electron
density of the carbon–carbon double bond. These reactions lead to electrophilic addition.

C33AEEBD13154A40A05605B066D589CB.description:
An electrophile is a reactant that forms a bond to its reaction partner (the
nucleophile) by accepting both bonding electrons from that reaction partner

2540C49D30BF4EA0B653611EDA612106.description:
Heterolytic fission is the breakage of a covalent bond when both bonding
electrons remain with one of the two fragments formed.

48D0B7CBA2EE48E084683BABD0F18B42.description:
In a nucleophilic substitution reaction, a nucleophile donates an electron pair to
form a new bond, as another bond breaks producing a leaving group.

5B40F984586045D1B8F493ABA53B3168.description:
A nucleophile is a reactant that forms a bond to its reaction partner (the
electrophile) by donating both bonding electrons.

6D99E5F71188475E811059742454A338.description:
Radicals take part in substitution reactions with alkanes, producing a mixture of
products.

3EFD8ED7FE1346569FB7E0AA119805DB.description:
Radicals are produced by homolytic fission, e.g. of halogens, in the presence of
ultraviolet (UV) light or heat.

13649669F27C474EB5A63B0820095D57.description:
A radical is a molecular entity that has an unpaired electron. Radicals are highly
reactive.

934F4B2BB00C4C0299139B552307D3AA.description:
Electroplating involves the electrolytic coating of an object with a metallic thin
layer.

485BAE9361F64D2CAB7D23F2A2F86AF2.description:
During electrolysis of aqueous solutions, competing reactions can occur at the
anode and cathode, including the oxidation and reduction of water.

ACBEEB71826A43E79C3B5BCD82399A15.description:
The equation ΔG⦵ = − nFE⦵
cell shows the relationship between standard
change in Gibbs energy and standard cell potential for a reaction

6A468087C02540599BFE1F9F2A40D91C.description:
Standard cell potential, E⦵
cell, can be calculated from standard electrode
potentials. E⦵
cell has a positive value for a spontaneous reaction.

178D6FCD7CBF42DEA029B4B27BB4B621.description:
The hydrogen half-cell H+(aq) + e− ⇌12
H2(g) is assigned a standard electrode
potential of zero by convention. It is used in the measurement of standard electrode potential, E⦵.

2119E8DFED4F45CAA8F41FD550920D09.description:
Reduction of unsaturated compounds by the addition of hydrogen lowers the
degree of unsaturation.

08472A141CED4427947FE8301AF2E241.description: Functional groups in organic compounds may undergo reduction.

0F58FB5F86704BDC875985F253B158CC.description: Functional groups in organic compounds may undergo oxidation.

34136D83CFBB414BB99E71DD574D5F53.description:
An electrolytic cell is an electrochemical cell that converts electrical energy to
chemical energy by bringing about non-spontaneous reactions.

0ADBC93EC5DE4DCBB5A2DDD99B992032.description:
Secondary (rechargeable) cells involve redox reactions that can be reversed using
electrical energy.

31BDA5C0258445B78CF7B69CBE04583A.description:
A primary (voltaic) cell is an electrochemical cell that converts energy from
spontaneous redox reactions to electrical energy.

0679035C68FC4100A3BCCD9380A758DD.description:
Oxidation occurs at the anode and reduction occurs at the cathode in
electrochemical cells.

D9E8AB64B1AF489DA9FE6C24ED0DC88F.description: Acids react with reactive metals to release hydrogen.

A71ED889CAEA487C9CC853B826BBA6F9.description:
The relative ease of oxidation and reduction of an element in a group can be
predicted from its position in the periodic table.
The reactions between metals and aqueous metal ions demonstrate the relative ease of oxidation of
different metals.

C153E6A2A5684E68BDE3E4D18AA4F5DE.description:
Half-equations separate the processes of oxidation and reduction, showing the
loss or gain of electrons.

3BFB4598C4B34FE1AFD27E5842E4C23F.description:
Oxidation and reduction can be described in terms of electron transfer, change in
oxidation state, oxygen gain/loss or hydrogen loss/gain.

8B47741A847442639BC234E1C46C1A7C.description:
The pH of a buffer solution depends on both: • the pKa or pKb of its acid or base
• the ratio of the concentration of acid or base to the concentration of the conjugate base or
acid.

88253CC9E5BB401998B74EB3D561BB1B.description:
A buffer solution is one that resists change in pH on the addition of small
amounts of acid or alkali.

897A24A2E1CB4A6B97ACF1A66E367CB0.description:
An appropriate indicator for a titration has an end point range that coincides
with the pH at the equivalence point

04D645E183854A08B60B3EEFE9CDE256.description:
Acid–base indicators are weak acids, where the components of the conjugate
acid–base pair have different colours. The pH of the end point of an indicator, where it changes
colour, approximately corresponds to its pKa value.

F5DFF3884F854B81A3A3593C71CCE18D.description:
pH curves of different combinations of strong and weak monoprotic acids and
bases have characteristic shapes and features.

EAE8D5623560479F837D4AB9B1D0F267.description:
The pH of a salt solution depends on the relative strengths of the parent acid and
base.

8DEDD955BE524789BAB6B3E04D5A4E12.description:
For a conjugate acid–base pair, the relationship Ka × Kb = Kw can be derived
from the expressions for Ka and Kb

A2E6B1ECC7DF4CEA98E52E375C85B18F.description:
The strengths of weak acids and bases are described by their Ka, Kb, pKa or pKb
values.

BB99B0EC2EC646F59A824860C59AF3F5.description: The pOH scale describes the [OH–] of a solution. pOH = –log10[OH–]; [OH–] = 10–pOH

B6B0CED5F00849D2AB7FF53AA7031715.description:
pH curves for neutralization reactions involving strong acids and bases have
characteristic shapes and features.

5E47A81D11094C6597D18080C746C6AE.description: Acids react with bases in neutralization reactions

1F969AD36D704997B788D96F3037F52C.description: Strong and weak acids and bases differ in the extent of ionization.

3BB46510F770443B8E79B13F3D3C702F.description:
The ion product constant of water, Kw, shows an inverse relationship between [H+]
and [OH–]. Kw = [H+] [OH–]

5F522608D592491896C2B30B8E16DA7F.description:
The pH scale can be used to describe the [H+] of a solution:
pH = –log10[H+]; [H+] = 10–pH

D1DF3D07274D4DEF8E759DF23D25B239.description: Some species can act as both Brønsted–Lowry acids and bases.

7A1F011BDE4B4F2796AC810B2BF899B8.description: A pair of species differing by a single proton is called a conjugate acid–base pair

6343F4E4D013447A89D77CE3CFC10D5B.description:
Brønsted–Lowry acid is a proton donor and a Brønsted–Lowry base is a proton
acceptor.

C6E402FE67414C5FA4F5A3C247F7CEB7.description: What are the mechanisms of chemical change?

D7C9EAA9B23D4D3781A83D31C4A35BCB.description:
The equilibrium constant and Gibbs energy change, ΔG, can both be used to
measure the position of an equilibrium reaction.

A79B2DB4EFE942BE84A41B41B33618D3.description:
The equilibrium law is the basis for quantifying the composition of an equilibrium
mixture.

A7DE2D84709D44119695C749BDCD73FE.description:
The reaction quotient, Q, is calculated using the equilibrium expression with nonequilibrium
concentrations of reactants and products.

C523C27EE6104A248B317FEF3CF3F23D.description:
Le Châtelier’s principle enables the prediction of the qualitative effects of changes
in concentration, temperature and pressure to a system at equilibrium.

C895F37C02234DBC8D120A80AA45694C.description:
The magnitude of the equilibrium constant indicates the extent of a reaction at
equilibrium and is temperature dependent

5E9F28412EF84C0CB959322D7B04D53C.description:
The equilibrium law describes how the equilibrium constant, K, can be
determined from the stoichiometry of a reaction.

F827E1553B52483EB021A9D734330DB8.description:
A state of dynamic equilibrium is reached in a closed system when the rates of
forward and backward reactions are equal

FF61F9334EE24B5DB4D6C3D1246C209A.description: How far? The extent of chemical change

4AE0D371234247BBA8237ADC7FA08467.description:
The Arrhenius factor, A, takes into account the frequency of collisions with
proper orientations.

22A11E9EC9624CF1A9F511F3BD21C6AC.description:
The Arrhenius equation uses the temperature dependence of the rate constant
to determine the activation energy.

5B748E0961AF4F4A98E0E15B298F8153.description:
The rate constant, k, is temperature dependent and its units are determined
from the overall order of the reaction.

0E42D78F2838426AB2BAFB6473447238.description:
The order of a reaction with respect to a reactant is the exponent to which the
concentration of the reactant is raised in the rate equation.
The order with respect to a reactant can describe the number of particles taking part in the rate determining
step.
The overall reaction order is the sum of the orders with respect to each reactant.

263A88CF131147FBAB269C9FDEA4C7D9.description:
Rate equations depend on the mechanism of the reaction and can only be
determined experimentally

AD98CEE29B9F4919B8248271388E3E48.description:
The molecularity of an elementary step is the number of reacting particles taking
part in that step.

7E0E7BA607AB49589AFD50CF26EA1FD3.description:
Energy profiles can be used to show the activation energy and transition state of
the rate-determining step in a multistep reaction.

DCE6174A17364702BDB544265A45BC92.description:
Many reactions occur in a series of elementary steps. The slowest step determines
the rate of the reaction.

F84D49AEF0014CA6B87E8A3051F0A52A.description:
Catalysts increase the rate of reaction by providing an alternative reaction
pathway with lower Ea.

20C80C3BC81D416190AAAD9997988342.description:
Activation energy, Ea, is the minimum energy that colliding particles need for a
successful collision leading to a reaction.

FBFA0509AEAA4966A73837ACD27BFC18.description:
Factors that influence the rate of a reaction include pressure, concentration,
surface area, temperature and the presence of a catalyst.

B4FD1B1715664CACB647CC57E08C9CDF.description: Species react as a result of collisions of sufficient energy and proper orientation.

DD1E3724A19F48D99B18C8B49BF3DA85.description:
The rate of reaction is expressed as the change in concentration of a particular
reactant/product per unit time.

53173FA456C74B14A21D0CE9410AC0C6.description: How fast? The rate of chemical change

62CF8DB44FA04E10A014CCECE63F8BBB.description: The atom economy is a measure of efficiency in green chemistry.

A0CF129EAD25412C9BEA48CBFFD6F2AC.description:
The percentage yield is calculated from the ratio of experimental yield to
theoretical yield.

E20BDDF99EED408898AA735141644A62.description: The limiting reactant determines the theoretical yield.

D43AD7E3FDF54AF1A7F7B423346E1660.description:
The mole ratio of an equation can be used to determine:
• the masses and/or volumes of reactants and products
• the concentrations of reactants and products for reactions occurring in solution.

DFFD962E6B7C4EC1AA4AB02CB41FA9F3.description: Chemical equations show the ratio of reactants and products in a reaction

2B544B5330A54C62B60805FC66742D97.description: How much? The amount of chemical change

4F1DE902351C422D9D2F61ABC1BC098B.description: How much, how fast and how far?

CCC31D4C797247FFBE88B1C3F780D960.description:
As a reaction approaches equilibrium, ΔG becomes less negative and finally
reaches zero.

BBD13BD5B3E24A1FAD930A2B686B0AF3.description:
At constant pressure, a change is spontaneous if the change in Gibbs energy, ΔG,
is negative.

8D812AAB66FB4E2099C28185CFD3EAC9.description:
Change in Gibbs energy, ΔG, relates the energy that can be obtained from a
chemical reaction to the change in enthalpy, ΔH, change in entropy, ΔS, and absolute temperature,
T.

5A4E9E431DAE407CAE34EDEF63289CA5.description:
Entropy, S, is a measure of the dispersal or distribution of matter and/or energy in
a system. The more ways the energy can be distributed, the higher the entropy. Under the same
conditions, the entropy of a gas is greater than that of a liquid, which in turn is greater than that of a
solid.

42C45B7AE91B402B963952B991FB46EC.description:
A fuel cell can be used to convert chemical energy from a fuel directly to electrical
energy.

343A2116B2804C2A8C1FD2408DF511B0.description:
Biofuels are produced from the biological fixation of carbon over a short period of
time through photosynthesis.

EDB9DE45ED3C4069986E9A547A86C79D.description:
Fossil fuels include coal, crude oil and natural gas, which have different
advantages and disadvantages.

37C6A77807BA44D1A802D0CC0DC320D4.description:
Incomplete combustion of organic compounds, especially hydrocarbons, leads to
the production of carbon monoxide and carbon.

38A4FE281EAD470AA0A0FD9EEC8D3331.description:
Reactive metals, non-metals and organic compounds undergo combustion
reactions when heated in oxygen.

784981CB32DF418BBB88D33EB296F680.description:
A Born–Haber cycle is an application of Hess’s law, used to show energy changes
in the formation of an ionic compound.

6FB19DEFD787475FA9168B9E8BCCA0C3.description:
An application of Hess’s law uses enthalpy of formation data or enthalpy of
combustion data to calculate the enthalpy change of a reaction.

FF1406A860794124BEB41553A39D77DE.description:
Standard enthalpy changes of combustion, ΔHc
⦵, and formation, ΔHf
⦵, data are
used in thermodynamic calculations.

E02F98CCAA1A47098CE0A9AF72D33599.description:
Hess’s law states that the enthalpy change for a reaction is independent of the
pathway between the initial and final states.

FD612906B5784381B237B9F0077A08E2.description: Bond-breaking absorbs and bond-forming releases energy.

F8394804658945CA906A3F1B78D8FAAB.description:
The standard enthalpy change for a chemical reaction, ΔH⦵, refers to the heat
transferred at constant pressure under standard conditions and states. It can be determined from
the change in temperature of a pure substance.

A444F025F58A4132BAA3586DF39F5C86.description:
The relative stability of reactants and products determines whether reactions are
endothermic or exothermic.

BB8E0FA8784341E2A752C8D2568B9ED6.description:
Reactions are described as endothermic or exothermic, depending on the
direction of energy transfer between the system and the surroundings.

8A8DE5E9CC694B51908B05EB1503ADC0.description:
Chemical reactions involve a transfer of energy between the system and the
surroundings, while total energy is conserved.

59C45BA6A02149BE91C9E5A2ACEDCDFA.description: Data from different techniques are often combined in structural analysis.

FC27DB7194D145958FA617D5AE74DEE5.description: Individual signals can be split into clusters of peaks.

75D9335F418C45BDBDB2B3F8BC789F93.description:
Proton nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H NMR) gives information on
the different chemical environments of hydrogen atoms in a molecule.

8E66F7842B64480888F84842D8DB53C3.description: Infrared (IR) spectra can be used to identify the type of bond present in a molecule.

1BCC537415C44A23829A4D01CE75BA5F.description:
Mass spectrometry (MS) of organic compounds can cause fragmentation of
molecules.

0F853E1C777B45C385BEE5C09FBC87F7.description:
Stereoisomers have the same constitution (atom identities, connectivities and
bond multiplicities) but different spatial arrangements of atoms.

1F053A4703A44611B2EEB339E642D04D.description:
Structural isomers are molecules that have the same molecular formula but
different connectivities.

E1FED5DCEE264802B93B6E9FD5DD0BAF.description:
“IUPAC nomenclature” refers to a set of rules used by the International Union of
Pure and Applied Chemistry to apply systematic names to organic and inorganic compounds.

FA3F39776CD143478723CAEE8E9013EA.description: Successive members of a homologous series show a trend in physical properties.

571E884E36DB484EACD057CD53DF0A95.description:
A homologous series is a family of compounds in which successive members differ
by a common structural unit, typically CH2. Each homologous series can be described by a general
formula.

6E8A45B649CE4A72B1093F2B2E2783DD.description:
Functional groups give characteristic physical and chemical properties to a
compound. Organic compounds are divided into classes according to the functional groups present
in their molecules.

347E0354268847ECBFB39D3377E1EB47.description:
Organic compounds can be represented by different types of formulas. These
include empirical, molecular, structural (full and condensed), stereochemical and skeletal.

8D33C55F946F4EE1BAADC47D7B9D3EB3.description: Functional groups: Classification of organic compounds

38284EDE661E4B85A421E54842D4A947.description:
Transition element complexes are coloured due to the absorption of light when
an electron is promoted between the orbitals in the split d-sublevels. The colour absorbed is
complementary to the colour observed.

75741099B5C84EECAC0B91C823B80672.description:
The formation of variable oxidation states in transition elements can be explained
by the fact that their successive ionization energies are close in value.

E9AB49888C5B4330AE588AD1145959CD.description:
Transition elements have incomplete d-sublevels that give them characteristic
properties.

D7185125075C42659281F6AD0253FA3B.description:
Discontinuities occur in the trend of increasing first ionization energy across a
period.

B534FE5651AE45BCA1A5838998940B9F.description:
The oxidation state is a number assigned to an atom to show the number of
electrons transferred in forming a bond. It is the charge that atom would have if the compound
were composed of ions.

12A1F948479E474E9F1FAFF0681A5AA1.description:
Metallic and non-metallic properties show a continuum. This includes the trend
from basic metal oxides through amphoteric to acidic non-metal oxides.

D9CE4FC529924AF6A571B54739C57ED1.description:
Trends in properties of elements down a group include the increasing metallic
character of group 1 elements and decreasing non-metallic character of group 17 elements.

4098CCC032A340DC92EC7D2C87CC0A24.description:
Periodicity refers to trends in properties of elements across a period and down a
group.

F437EE13C16141A1A8CA6CCECB999CBA.description:
The period number shows the outer energy level that is occupied by electrons.
Elements in a group have a common number of valence electrons.

AC754D4C029E4CF8818DA2D9F5EE14E8.description: The periodic table consists of periods, groups and blocks.

DCD98B3D92054B88A02BC9DBDB445C3C.description: The periodic table: Classification of elements

74E3F7DB09D540CA8321CA79F8ADE144.description:
Condensation polymers form by the reaction between functional groups in each
monomer with the release of a small molecule.

CB28E887D4EE416F9D84265ED3F1FF9C.description: Addition polymers form by the breaking of a double bond in each monomer.

54B62D8FE4AE42E4978565354AEACDBD.description:
Polymers are large molecules, or macromolecules, made from repeating subunits
called monomers.

42902B2991484D438A31BF578C7EBCBF.description:
Alloys are mixtures of a metal and other metals or non-metals. They have
enhanced properties.

5BE6B20359EE49DD95537426BFB2901C.description:
The position of a compound in the bonding triangle is determined by the relative
contributions of the three bonding types to the overall bond.

0082BDD3A0274029956B65189BCB33DE.description:
Bonding is best described as a continuum between the ionic, covalent and metallic
models, and can be represented by a bonding triangle

61F5C0250B794BD3A34D759E134EA765.description:
The strength of a metallic bond depends on the charge of the ions and the radius
of the metal ion.

9726499EF85743B9A5727B95F452E6F1.description:
A metallic bond is the electrostatic attraction between a lattice of cations and
delocalized electrons.

37A858978CDD492B8101A580A685425F.description:
Hybridization is the concept of mixing atomic orbitals to form new hybrid
orbitals for bonding.

AF14EA0734D44746817F9B1FF66055DD.description:
2.2.15—Sigma bonds σ form by the head-on combination of atomic orbitals where the
electron density is concentrated along the bond axis.
Pi bonds π form by the lateral combination of p-orbitals where the electron density is
concentrated on opposite sides of the bond axis.

E4B547C3758D43CBA7D94AED09FF505E.description:
Formal charge values can be calculated for each atom in a species and used to
determine which of several possible Lewis formulas is preferred.

867C841E913849C4A41968B7317D9C00.description:
Some atoms can form molecules in which they have an expanded octet of
electrons.

5F608EFED3B74A268C8BC4CC846F2D7B.description: Benzene, C6H6, is an important example of a molecule that has resonance.

3380418EFC2E4E968B39D890A814325A.description:
Resonance structures occur when there is more than one possible position for a
double bond in a molecule.

8657EE0AD64D460288EDC7DDFBD36293.description:
Chromatography is a technique used to separate the components of a mixture
based on their relative attractions involving intermolecular forces to mobile and stationary phases.

C3FC65A36B8544A283B34AB502F23AAC.description:
Given comparable molar mass, the relative strengths of intermolecular forces are
generally: London (dispersion) forces < dipole–dipole forces < hydrogen bonding

E929759190364C5AA1A9BCB380AAC1FE.description:
The nature of the force that exists between molecules is determined by the size
and polarity of the molecules. Intermolecular forces include London (dispersion), dipole-induced
dipole, dipole–dipole and hydrogen bonding.

1A0DDF7731474F98864315E9208EDAD8.description: Carbon and silicon form covalent network structures

1B712A93585A4CC1A80511F1D219AEEC.description: Molecular polarity depends on both bond polarity and molecular geometry.

FDD31E1658B24C1680BFD410A87382C8.description:
Bond polarity results from the difference in electronegativities of the bonded
atoms.

CD9945CD4C2444219BB51DE42131F77E.description:
The valence shell electron pair repulsion (VSEPR) model enables the shapes of
molecules to be predicted from the repulsion of electron domains around a central atom.

ABA977854AA843AC801AB3F8C19D8DAE.description:
A coordination bond is a covalent bond in which both the electrons of the shared
pair originate from the same atom.

A8BC512223BD46D8A68F40D9E2E90A8B.description:
Single, double and triple bonds involve one, two and three shared pairs of
electrons respectively.

E6B737341C574F36A47E4B0A71734F73.description:
A covalent bond is formed by the electrostatic attraction between a shared pair of
electrons and the positively charged nuclei.
The octet rule refers to the tendency of atoms to gain a valence shell with a total of 8 electrons.

9115D51650CA45EE8DF4626D0A28717F.description:
Ionic compounds exist as three-dimensional lattice structures, represented by
empirical formulas.

659C88B86602442F8DD288C7061270FC.description:
The ionic bond is formed by electrostatic attractions between oppositely charged
ions. Binary ionic compounds are named with the cation first, followed by the anion. The anion adopts
the suffix “ide”.

6A7A5FB1601F4417B6CD2B92489FBFB5.description:
When metal atoms lose electrons, they form positive ions called cations.
When non-metal atoms gain electrons, they form negative ions called anions.

EEA06574687F4D57BA4D104757B1457E.description:
The relationship between the pressure, volume, temperature and amount of an
ideal gas is shown in the ideal gas equation PV = nRT and the combined gas law
P1V1
T1
= P2V2
T2
.

936FAD34663F43DABCEC60FCE6B30D69.description:
The molar volume of an ideal gas is a constant at a specific temperature and
pressure.

2DADD4FCDE2F406C82440ABCE0F10120.description:
Real gases deviate from the ideal gas model, particularly at low temperature and
high pressure.

FDB6A80FB93F4E7EB6805849930F4DCA.description:
An ideal gas consists of moving particles with negligible volume and no
intermolecular forces. All collisions between particles are considered elastic.

E763385B8A0644A8B946F487D8C5AD66.description:
Avogadro’s law states that equal volumes of all gases measured under the same
conditions of temperature and pressure contain equal numbers of molecules.

4E7DEA1581C149E6BB2CEC03AF706FE2.description:
The molar concentration is determined by the amount of solute and the volume of
solution.

C217BA6D12EE450BB9A3E131407F0C35.description:
The empirical formula of a compound gives the simplest ratio of atoms of each
element present in that compound. The molecular formula gives the actual number of atoms of
each element present in a molecule.

794412A5018D4386B0D44ABED881B51E.description: Molar mass M has the units g mol–1.

871EFA2FE1A748E4AA4895FFB6EEBE62.description:
Masses of atoms are compared on a scale relative to 12C and are expressed as
relative atomic mass Ar and relative formula mass Mr .

2373E61862594307BF5997A03B49722B.description:
The mole (mol) is the SI unit of amount of substance. One mole contains exactly
the number of elementary entities given by the Avogadro constant.

7BA1D7B607AD45C5998E5348A3E65F59.description: Counting particles by mass: The mole

C9DEA4268C5348B9BD3921B847939902.description:
Successive ionization energy (IE) data for an element give information about its
electron configuration.

5D9DAA2653FA46B38AD9B314880BAF51.description:
In an emission spectrum, the limit of convergence at higher frequency corresponds
to ionization.

0CE8A83FD0F34E219960BF51B60685A2.description:
Each orbital has a defined energy state for a given electron configuration and
chemical environment, and can hold two electrons of opposite spin.
Sublevels contain a fixed number of orbitals, regions of space where there is a high probability of
finding an electron.

216D4505583F412B8174E2ADF296B287.description:
A more detailed model of the atom describes the division of the main energy level
into s, p, d and f sublevels of successively higher energies.

43A079F959FC4E358DB7301857538EE7.description:
The main energy level is given an integer number, n, and can hold a maximum of
2n2 electrons.

7DA65521B36C4197906C33C33532C7B9.description:
The line emission spectrum of hydrogen provides evidence for the existence of
electrons in discrete energy levels, which converge at higher energies.

C3289B4817A94DD9BD6B873C3B472955.description:
Emission spectra are produced by atoms emitting photons when electrons in
excited states return to lower energy levels.

896439BEF95E4CA68A8F989E4181CE18.description:
Mass spectra are used to determine the relative atomic masses of elements from
their isotopic composition.

29F9516302E94A6B997ABF7F86E47A38.description: Isotopes are atoms of the same element with different numbers of neutrons.

F9775613F9A445B49B7FC90362083266.description:
Atoms contain a positively charged, dense nucleus composed of protons and
neutrons (nucleons). Negatively charged electrons occupy the space outside the nucleus.

01B2AD45299B4217A543B55997F3645A.description:
The temperature, T, in Kelvin (K) is a measure of average kinetic energy Ek of
particles.

A2EF8C8BDA55446F95695A9351F27A84.description:
The kinetic molecular theory is a model to explain physical properties of matter
(solids, liquids and gases) and changes of state.

621603AC90764E8B87691DA6BDE19DD2.description:
Elements are the primary constituents of matter, which cannot be chemically
broken down into simpler substances.
Compounds consist of atoms of different elements chemically bonded together in a fixed ratio.
Mixtures contain more than one element or compound in no fixed ratio, which are not chemically
bonded and so can be separated by physical methods.

6CC4610482F846B39835A12855DD8C1F.description: Introduction to the particulate nature of matter

E71F30C033DE41C48A82D0BE009DB87B.description: Models of the particulate nature of matter
